1.brief: properly, to sit down (specifically as judge. in ambush, in quiet); by implication, to dwell, to remain; causatively, to settle, to marry
a city (a place guarded by waking or a watch) in the widest sense (even of a mere encampment or post)
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
a widow; also a desolate place
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)
a foreign nation; hence, a Gentile; also (figuratively) a troop of animals, or a flight of locusts
properly, a judgeship, i.e. jurisdiction; by implication, a district (as ruled by a judge); generally, a region
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
properly, a burden (as causing to faint), i.e. a tax in the form of forced labor

2.brief: properly, a twist (away of the light), i.e. night; figuratively, adversity
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
the cheek (from its fleshiness); hence, the jaw-bone
a non-entity; generally used as a negative particle
properly, to sigh, i.e. breathe strongly; by implication, to be sorry, i.e. (in a favorable sense) to pity, console or (reflexively) rue; or (unfavorably) to avenge (oneself)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
to have affection for (sexually or otherwise)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
to cover (with a garment); figuratively, to act covertly; by implication, to pillage
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)

3.brief: to denude (especially in a disgraceful sense); by implication, to exile (captives being usually stripped); figuratively, to reveal
Jehudah (or Judah), the name of five Israelites; also of the tribe descended from the first, and of its territory

he (she or it); only expressed when emphatic or without a verb; also (intensively) self, or (especially with the article) the same; sometimes (as demonstrative) this or that; occasionally (instead of copula) as or are
properly, to sit down (specifically as judge. in ambush, in quiet); by implication, to dwell, to remain; causatively, to settle, to marry
a foreign nation; hence, a Gentile; also (figuratively) a troop of animals, or a flight of locusts
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
properly, to come forth to, i.e. appear or exist; transitively, to attain, i.e. find or acquire; figuratively, to occur, meet or be present
quiet, i.e. (concretely) a settled spot, or (figuratively) a home
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
to run after (usually with hostile intent; figuratively (of time) gone by)
between (repeated before each noun, often with other particles); also as a conjunction, either...or

4.brief: a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
Tsijon (as a permanent capital), a mountain of Jerusalem
properly, failure, i.e. nothing or destruction; usually (with preposition) without, not yet, because not, as long as, etc.
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)

properly, an appointment, i.e. a fixed time or season; specifically, a festival; conventionally ayear; by implication, an assembly (as convened for a definite purpose); technically the congregation; by extension, the place of meeting; also a signal (as appointed beforehand)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
an opening, i.e. door or gate
to stun (or intransitively, grow numb), i.e. devastate or (figuratively) stupefy (both usually in a passive sense)
literally one officiating, a priest; also (by courtesy) an acting priest (although a layman)
a virgin (from her privacy); sometimes (by continuation) a bride; also (figuratively) a city or state

he (she or it); only expressed when emphatic or without a verb; also (intensively) self, or (especially with the article) the same; sometimes (as demonstrative) this or that; occasionally (instead of copula) as or are
bitter (literally or figuratively); also (as noun) bitterness, or (adverbially) bitterly

narrow; (as a noun) a tight place (usually figuratively, i.e. trouble); also a pebble ; (transitive) an opponent (as crowding)
the head (as most easily shaken), whether literal or figurative (in many applications, of place, time, rank, itc.)
to be tranquil, i.e. secure or successful

properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)
the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything
